name: heat production, borehole heat exchanger, brine-water heat pump 10kW | heat, brine-water heat pump 10kW | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/8092/documentation

This dataset represents the production of heat with a brine-water heat pump and a borehole heat exchanger for an average one family house in the Swiss midland. Switzerland is assumed to represent an average climatological and geological location in Europe. The brine-water heat pump has a heat capacity of 10 kW and a Seasonal Performance Factor (SPF) of 3.9 (for the year 1998). Data for the estimation of SPF is based on a field study for Swiss heat pumps and on various literature. Life time is assumed to be 20 years for the heat pump and 50 years for the borehole heat exchanger. This dataset is based on the following reference values: for the average one family house a heating requirement of 10 kW, a heat distribution system (low-temperature system) of 50/40°C and a heat supply of approximately 20.000 kWh with 2.000 operating hours were assumed. Furthermore, a system with a heating output of 10,25 kW (at a supply temperature of 40°C), a mean cooling capacity of 8,25 kW (to dimension the borehole heat exchanger) and a extraction performance of 55 W/m were chosen. The system is assumed to be operated without an auxiliary heating system. ;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From geothermal energy entering the borehole heat exchanger.

This activity ends with heat at the brine-water heat pump with a life time of 20 years. This dataset includes emissions of refrigerant R134a during operation. This dataset doesn´t include the heat distribution in the one family house, nor a buffer heat storage.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/353:Steam and air conditioning supply/3530:Steam and air conditioning supply

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The Seasonal Performance Factor (SPF) is an important figure which indicates the ratio between heat amount at heat pump (respectively at storage if available) and specific demand for electricity of the heat pump (incl. all common auxiliaries). The Seasonal Performance Factors are estimated, based on a comprehensive field study for heat pump installations in Switzerland. ;Projections based on measures result on average in a SPF (SPF 2) of 3.2 for heat pumps installed in 1998 in Switzerland. (Erb et al. 2000) Heat pumps installed in 1994/95 in Switzerland showed on average a SPF of 2.6. (Erb&Hubacher 2001a) Measurements over several years have indicated that the factor hasn’t declined with age. Hence constant Seasonal Performance Factors can be assumed. The difference between values for Swiss SPF and measured COP-values of WPZ is less than 10 %. Half of the sample is at least to some extent used for heating domestic hot water. (Erb et al. 2000);;While until 1998 the analysis of Erb&Hubacher indicates rising SP factors, the COP values have risen continuously until 1995 but then have remained constant, according to measurements of the WPZ (Wärmepumpentestzentrum Winterthur-Tölz). (Roth 2001) Hence a good combination of heat pump systems and building technology is essential to achieve a good SPF. (Halozan 2002);;The estimation of the Seasonal Performance Factor is based on a COP-value (Coefficient of Performance) for a B0/W35 system of 3.47 to 4.84, averaged it amounts to 3,83. These values have been measured for brine-water heat pumps with a heat capacity between 9 and 11 kW until 22nd. January 1996 (WPZ 1996). In the year 1996, heat pump manufacturer indicated COP-values between 3 and 3.5. (Multi-Energie, Grünewald 1996); responsible authorities in Zürich and Solothurn indicated values between 3.2 and 3.5 for new systems and a COP of 3 for existing systems. (Energiefachstelle Solothurn 1996, BfK 1996). Measurements of existing systems showed values between 2.2 and 3.9 (2.6 on average). (Hubacher 1996);References:;Erb M., Eicher H., Hubacher P.: Feldanalyse von Wärmepumpenanlagen. In: 11. Schweizerisches Status-Seminar. 14./15. September 2000, ETH Zürich. ZEN (Zentrum für Energie und Nachhaltigkeit im Bauwesen). Tagungsband. EMPA ZEN. Dübendorf. September 2000.;Erb M and Hubacher P: Field analysis of Swiss heat pump installations. IEA Heat Pump Centre Newsletter. Volume 19 - No. 1/2001. Available from: www.heatpumpcentre.org;Roth S., WPZ-Bulletin Nr. 28. Wärmepumpen-Testzentrum Winterthur Töss (WPZ).;Holozan H. (2002): Heat pumps and the environment. Proceedings of the 7th International Energy Agency Conference on Heat Pumping Technologies, Beijing, China, May 19-22, 2002.;WPZ-Bulletin Nr. 7, Wärmepumpentest- und Ausbildungszentrum Winterthur-Töss, 1996.;Persönliche Mitteilung der Firma Multi Energie AG, Aadorf, April 1996.;Persönliche Mitteilung der Firma Grünenwald AG, Affoltern a/A, April 1996.;Bundesamt für Konjunkturfragen, 'Umweltwärme effizient nutzen – Heizen mit Elektro-Wärme¬pumpen', PACER, Bern, 1996.;Messdaten der Firma Hubacher Engeneering, Engelburg, Juli 1996.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Literature and field study of Swiss heat pumps.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. With a heating capacity of 10 kW and operating hours of 2000 h/a the brine-water heat pump produces approx. 1,44E06 MJ of heat within a life time of 20 years. The reciprocal value indicates the amount of heat pumps required to produce one MJ of useful heat. Life time of the borehole heat exchanger is assumed to be 50 years, i.e. the infrastructure is decreased by a factor of 2.5.

The reciprocal value indicates the amount of heat pumps required to produce one MJ of useful heat. Life time of the borehole heat exchanger is assumed to be 50 years, i.e. the infrastructure is decreased by a factor of 2.5.

exchanges.description: Seasonal Performance Factor measured in Switzerland 1998; uncertainty from range of Coefficient of Performance.

Estimation. The Swiss electricity mix is used. Seasonal Performance Factor of 3.9 (in the year 1998) is estimated. The reciprocal value of the Seasonal Performance Factor (SPF) indicates the required amount of electricity in MJ per MJ of heat, at heat pump (divided by the factor of 3.6 to convert into kWh).
Estimation. The Swiss electricity mix is used. Seasonal Performance Factor of 3.9 (in the year 1998) is estimated. The reciprocal value of the Seasonal Performance Factor (SPF) indicates the required amount of electricity in MJ per MJ of heat, at heat pump (divided by the factor of 3.6 to convert into kWh).

exchanges.description: Estimation. During operation leakage losses occur, which result in refrigerant emissions to air. In Frischknecht (Appendix Tab. 6.1) refrigerant losses between 5 % and 8 % are indicated, based on four different literature sources; one literature source indicates refrigerant losses between 1 % and 4 %. In this dataset 6 % of refrigerant losses are assumed with an uncertainty of SDg2  = 1,7 due to the range of literature values. Assuming operating hours of 2000 h/a the heat pump with a heat capacity of 10 kW produces 72.000 MJ/a. With a filling quantity of 3 kg refrigerant emissions of 2.5E-06 kg/MJ can be estimated. Taking a life time of 20 years into account, this amounts to 3,6 kg. Thus, on average losses during operation are bigger than the filling quantity.

flow.name: 1,1,1,2-Tetrafluoroethane

exchanges.description:
Estimation. A 10 kW brine-water heat pump unit for an average one family house is used.

Brine-water heat pumps use geothermal energy by extracting the heat stored in the ground with a borehole heat exchanger. The heat is withdrawn from the soil through a closed-loop system situated in the tube and is fed to the heat pump. As heat-conveying fluid, i.e. brine, in the majority of cases water is used compounded with 25 % to 35% of antifreezing agent. The heat pump then transforms the heat through a second circuit to an appropriate temperature level for low-temperature heating systems. Brine-water heat pumps are more expensive but have a higher annual coefficient of performance compared to air-water heat pumps, i.e. high quality energy is used in a more efficient way. According to Lovvorn and Hess life time of the heat pump is 20 years.

Further references:

Lovvorn, N.C. (2001). Reliability and Lifetime of Residential Heat Pumps. Paper. Proceedings of Joint HPC and IPUHPC Workshop 'Hands-On Experience with Heat Pumps for Buildings,' 10-11 October 2001. Arnhem, The Netherlands. CD-ROM: 'Hands-On Experience with Heat Pumps for Buildings,' Workshop Report HPC-WR-23. IEA Heat Pump Centre. Sittard, The Netherlands.

Lovvorn, N.C. (2001). Reliability and Lifetime of Residential Heat Pumps. Power Point Presentation. CD-ROM: 'Hands-On Experience with Heat Pumps for Buildings,' Workshop Report HPC-WR-23. IEA Heat Pump Centre. Sittard, The Netherlands.
Estimation. A 10 kW brine-water heat pump unit for an average one family house is used.

Brine-water heat pumps are more expensive but have a higher annual coefficient of performance compared to air-water heat pumps, i.e. high quality energy is used in a more efficient way. According to Lovvorn and Hess life time of the heat pump is 20 years.

Further references:

exchanges.description:
Estimation. Borehole heat exchangers basically consist of coaxial or U-shaped polyethylene tubes and are installed vertically in the soil, usually at a depth of 50 up to 250 meters. Thereby the soil serves as heat source. 

For  a borehole heat exchanger for an average one family house two U-shaped polyethylene tubes are installed in a borehole in the ground with a diameter of about 12 cm and a depth of 150 meters. Life time is assumed to be 50 years.
This exchange has an activity link directly to the producing activity because the product is primarily consumed in the same geographical area where it is produced.
